channel.title: NPR Programs: Morning Edition
channel.description: Morning Edition takes listeners around the country and the world with multi-faceted stories and commentaries every weekday. Hosts Steve Inskeep, Leila Fadel, Michel Martin and A Martínez bring you the latest breaking news and features to prepare you for the day.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: White House dismisses release of Epstein documents as a distraction from Democrats
item.description: The White House dismissed the release of new Jeffrey Epstein documents as a distraction by Democrats and maintained President Trump has done nothing wrong, but it's been a tough issue to shake.
item.content:encoded: The White House dismissed the release of new Jeffrey Epstein documents as a distraction by Democrats and maintained President Trump has done nothing wrong, but it's been a tough issue to shake.
item.dc:creator: Deepa Shivaram

item.title: NYU law professor talks about the fallout from the release of Epstein documents
item.description: NPR's Steve Inskeep speaks with New York University law professor Ryan Goodman about the fallout over the latest release of documents from the Epstein estate.
item.content:encoded: NPR's Steve Inskeep speaks with New York University law professor Ryan Goodman about the fallout over the latest release of documents from the Epstein estate.
item.dc:creator: Steve Inskeep

item.title: North Carolina sheriff on the deployment of Border Patrol agents in Charlotte
item.description: NPR's Leila Fadel speaks with Sheriff Garry McFadden of Mecklenberg County, North Carolina, who says federal officials alerted him that Border Patrol agents are heading to Charlotte.
item.content:encoded: NPR's Leila Fadel speaks with Sheriff Garry McFadden of Mecklenberg County, North Carolina, who says federal officials alerted him that Border Patrol agents are heading to Charlotte.
item.dc:creator: Leila Fadel

item.title: BBC apologizes for edit of Trump speech but says it won't provide legal compensation
item.description: The BBC has apologized to President Trump for the way it edited his Jan. 6, 2021, speech but says it won't pay compensation. Trump has threatened a $1 billion lawsuit against the British broadcaster.
item.content:encoded:
The BBC has apologized to President Trump for the way it edited his Jan. 6, 2021, speech but says it won't pay compensation. Trump has threatened a $1 billion lawsuit against the British broadcaster.

(Image credit: Kin Cheung)
item.dc:creator: Willem Marx

item.title: Morning news brief
item.description: White House dismisses release of new Epstein documents as a distraction, Border Patrol agents will be deployed to Charlotte, North Carolina, economists begin to calculate the cost of the shutdown.
item.content:encoded: White House dismisses release of new Epstein documents as a distraction, Border Patrol agents will be deployed to Charlotte, North Carolina, economists begin to calculate the cost of the shutdown.
item.dc:creator: Leila Fadel

item.title: Ken Burns shares 3 thoughts on upcoming 'American Revolution' series
item.description: In his latest project, Ken Burns turns his lens to the American Revolution — an event he has called the most significant since the birth of Christ.
item.content:encoded:
The American Revolution during the 2025 Atlantic Festival on September 18 in New York City.'/>

In his latest project, Ken Burns turns his lens to the American Revolution — an event he has called the most significant since the birth of Christ.

(Image credit: Michael Loccisano)
item.dc:creator: Michel Martin

item.title: Tallying up the cost of the longest government shutdown in U.S. history
item.description: Economists are starting to put a price tag on the six-week government shutdown. But some of their calculations will be difficult to make because the shutdown temporarily limited government data.
item.content:encoded: Economists are starting to put a price tag on the six-week government shutdown. But some of their calculations will be difficult to make because the shutdown temporarily limited government data.
item.dc:creator: Scott Horsley

item.title: Ecuador to vote on whether to allow foreign military bases back in the country
item.description: Ecuadorians will vote Sunday on whether to reverse a constitutional ban and allow foreign military bases back in the country, as part of the fight against drug trafficking.
item.content:encoded: Ecuadorians will vote Sunday on whether to reverse a constitutional ban and allow foreign military bases back in the country, as part of the fight against drug trafficking.
item.dc:creator: Carrie Kahn

item.title: Boston museum returns stoneware jars made by enslaved man to his descendants
item.description: The Museum of Fine Arts in Boston has returned two stoneware jars to the descendants of the enslaved man who made them. It's part of an effort to restore ownership of objects acquired unethically.
item.content:encoded: The Museum of Fine Arts in Boston has returned two stoneware jars to the descendants of the enslaved man who made them. It's part of an effort to restore ownership of objects acquired unethically.
item.dc:creator: Andrea Shea

item.title: Despite funding cuts, these teens are still answering calls for help
item.description: NPR's A Martinez speaks with Teen Line volunteers about how the peer-led support service continues providing mental health support, despite funding cuts to programs nationwide.
item.content:encoded: NPR's A Martinez speaks with Teen Line volunteers about how the peer-led support service continues providing mental health support, despite funding cuts to programs nationwide.
item.dc:creator: A Martínez
